{{for|the American bowler|George Pappas (bowler)}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = Western philosophy |era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] |image = |name = George Sotiros Pappas |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1942}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |school_tradition = |main_interests = [[Epistemology]], early [[Modern philosophy]], [[George Berkeley|Berkeley]] scholarship |notable_ideas = |influences = |influenced = |signature = |awards = International Berkeley Essay Prize (1993), Emeritus Professor }} '''George Sotiros Pappas''' (born 1942) is a professor of [[philosophy]] at [[Ohio State University]].[http://philosophy.osu.edu/people/person.cfm?ID=1292 Departmental profile at OSU] Pappas specializes in [[epistemology]], the history of [[early modern philosophy]], [[philosophy of religion]], and [[metaphysics]]. He is of Greek and English origin. He is the author of the [[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] entry on [[Internalism and externalism|Internalist versus Externalist]] conceptions of [[Theory of justification|epistemic justification]].[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-intext/ Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article] He was co-editor (with [[Marshall Swain]]) of ''Essays on Knowledge and Justification'' (1978), regarded as a key anthology of essays relating to the [[Gettier problem]][http://www.iep.utm.edu/g/gettier.htm#H15 Gettier Problem bibliography at the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy] and used as a core text in undergraduate [[epistemology]] courses.[http://www.ditext.com/clay/morris1.html Suggested epistemology reading list] George Pappas is an editorial consultant of [[Berkeley Studies]].{{cite web | url = http://people.hsc.edu/berkeleystudies/editorial.php | title = Berkeley Studies: Editorial Staff | accessdate = 2011-01-16 | year = | publisher = [[Hampden–Sydney College]] }} == Studies in Berkeley's philosophy == George S. Pappas is known to be a leading Berkeley scholar; his essay “Berkeley and Scepticism”{{cite journal |last=Pappas |first=G.S. |title=Berkeley and Scepticism |journal=[[Philosophy and Phenomenological Research]] |volume=59 |issue=1 |pages=133–149 |year=1999 |doi= 10.2307/2653461|url=}} was in 1993 awarded the International Berkeley Prize.See: [http://www.rochester.edu/college/PHL/Berkeleywinners.html Berkeley Prize Winners].
The annual International Berkeley Essay Prize competition was established by [[Colin Murray Turbayne]] and his wife in 1990. Professor Pappas is a regular participant of International Berkeley Conferences.[http://georgeberkeley.tamu.edu/conferences.html International Berkeley Conferences] At one such conference, celebrating the 300th anniversary of George Berkeley’s birth, Mr. Pappas propounded a new approach to the relationship between Berkeley’s anti-abstractionism and "esse est percipi"To be is to be perceived. A core proposition of Berkeley's ontology. principle. On Pappas reading, Berkeley’s two theses — that there are no abstract ideas and that sensible objects must be perceived in order to exist — entail one another.{{cite conference |last=Pappas |first=G.S. |chapter=Abstract ideas and the 'esse is percipi' thesis |editor-first=D. |editor-last=Berman |title=George Berkeley: Essays and replies |publisher=Irish Academic Press |location=Dublin |year=1985 |isbn=0-7165-2395-7 |pages=47–62 |conference=Proceedings of International Berkeley Conference in Dublin, 1985 |ref={{harvid|Essays and replies|1985}}}} {{quote|text = Pappas’ formulation of the relationship between these two propositions is ingenious and merits his verdict that it is a ‘very exciting result’ … So far as I know, his thesis is original. Some writers, to be sure, have some close to suggesting that the first proposition is a necessary condition for the truth of the second, but I cannot think of a commentator who holds that it is both a necessary and sufficient condition. |author= Avrum Stroll |source= Two lines of argumentation in Berkeley’s ''Principles'': a reply to George Pappas. In {{harvnb|Essays and replies|1985|p=140}}}} Pappas' interpretation of Berkeley's ‘''esse'' is ''percipi''’ thesis has sparked much discussion.{{cite journal| last=Stroll |first=Avrum |title=Two lines of argumentation in Berkeley’s Principles: a reply to George S. Pappas}} In {{harvnb|Essays and replies|1985|pp=139–145}}McKim, Robert. “Abstraction and Immaterialism: Recent Interpretations” // [[Berkeley Studies|Berkeley Newsletter]] 15 (1997–1998): 1–13. In 1989, the Garland Publishing Company brought out a 15-volume collection of major works on Berkeley; Pappas' paper “Abstract ideas and the 'esse is percipi' thesis” was included in the third volume,Berkeley on abstraction and abstract ideas / Ed. by W. Doney — N.Y.; L.: Garland, 1989. — XVII, 434 p. — (Philosophy of George Berkeley; 3; A Garland series) as it was considered to be a significant contribution to Berkeley scholarship. Pappas developed his treatment of Berkeley’s “esse est percipi” principle{{harvnb|Pappas|2000|pp=255–8. Ind.: p.257–261. (See chapter 5 ''Esse is percipi principle'')}} to repudiate the "inherence interpretation of Berkeley", upon which Edwin E. Allaire, among others, elaborated{{cite journal | last1 = Allaire | first1 = Edwin B. | year = 1963 | title = Berkeley's Idealism | journal = [[Theoria (philosophy journal)|Theoria]] | volume = XXIX | issue = 3 | pages = 229–44 | format = DjVu | accessdate = 2011-01-16 | url = http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6138_Allaire_Berkeley_s_idealism.djvu | doi=10.1111/j.1755-2567.1963.tb00025.x }}
The article is a classical work of Berkeley scholarship.For more detail, see: *{{cite journal |last=Hausman |first=A. |title=Adhering to inherence: A new look at the old steps in Berkeley's march to idealism |journal=[[Canadian Journal of Philosophy|Canad. J. of philosophy]] |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=421–443 |year=1984 |doi= 10.1080/00455091.1984.10716390|url= |ref=harv}} (A wide grasp of literature on the “inherence account”.) *{{cite book |first=Robert G. |last=Muehlmann |chapter=Introduction |title=Berkeley's Metaphysics: Structural, Interpretive, and Critical Essays |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zrvNFjIrDMUC |year=2010 |origyear=1995 |publisher=Pennsylvania State Press |isbn=0-271-04228-1}} (Muehlmann’s Introduction provides further bibliographical information of the various articles in defense and in criticism of this view.) *{{cite book |first=Katia |last=Saporiti |chapter=Ch. IV §2 Die Inhärenzhypothese |title=Die Wirklichkeit der Dinge: eine Untersuchung des Begriffs der Idee in der Philosophie George Berkeleys |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kS1Ux2jxMIMC&pg=PP1 |year=2006 |publisher=Vittorio Klostermann |isbn=978-3-465-03510-7 }} For up-to-date criticism of the “inherence account,” see: {{cite journal | last1 = Bettcher | first1 = Talia Mae (Ph. D., [[California State University, Los Angeles]]) | authorlink1 = | last2 = | first2 = | authorlink2 = | editor-last = | editor-first = | editor-link = |date= November 2008 | title = Berkeley's Dualistic Ontology| journal = [[Análisis Filosófico]] | volume = 28 | issue = 2 | series = | pages = 147–174 | publisher = | isbn = | pmid = | pmc = | bibcode = | doi = | accessdate = | url = http://www.calstatela.edu/faculty/tbettch/BerkeleyDualism.pdf | archiveurl = | archivedate = | ref = }}
“That account is put forward to answer an extremely perplexing question in the history of philosophy: Why did Berkeley embrace idealism, i. e., why did he hold that esse est percipi, that to be is to be perceived? {{harv|Hausman|1984|pp=421–2}}
After emerging in the early 1960s, the “inherence account” attracted numerous proponents and became an influential element of contemporary Berkeley scholarship. In his paper “Ideas, minds, and Berkeley”{{cite journal |last=Pappas |first=G.S. |title=Ideas, minds, and Berkeley |journal=[[American Philosophical Quarterly|Am. Phil. Q.]] |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=181–194 |year=1980 |doi= |url=http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6145_Pappas_Ideas%2C_Minds%2C_and_Berkeley.djvu}} Pappas revealed some discrepancies between fountain-head evidences and Allaire’s approach to a reconstruction of Berkeley’s idealism. Pappas' critical examination of the “inherence account” is greatly appreciated by Berkeley scholars. Pappas’ penetrating remarks compelled Edwin B. Allaire to revise and improve his conception.{{cite book |last=Allaire |first=Edwin B. |chapter=Berkeley’s Idealism Revisited |editor-first=Colin M. |editor-last=Turbayne |title=Berkeley: Critical and Interpretive Essays |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=RExF10reT9wC |year=1982 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |isbn=978-0-8166-1066-2 |pages=197–206}} Even those who share Allaire’s account of Berkeley’s idealism acknowledge Pappas’ article to be “an excellent review and critique of the IA [inherence account].”{{harvnb|Hausman|1984|p=422 (note 2)}} In 2000 George Pappas published his monograph ''Berkeley's thought'' in which some parts were based on earlier papers of his. While writings by [[A. A.
